Package com.rb.nonbiz.types

Class ClosedUnitFractionHardToSoftRangeTighteningInstructions

java.lang.Object
com.rb.nonbiz.types.ClosedUnitFractionHardToSoftRangeTighteningInstructions
public class ClosedUnitFractionHardToSoftRangeTighteningInstructions
extends java.lang.Object
Typically, when we construct a ClosedUnitFractionHardAndSoftRange, instead of specifying both hard and soft ranges independently, we only specify the hard range, and then further tighten it somewhat into a soft range.

For instance, if AAPL has a target of 4% in the index, we may specify the hard range as [0.02, 0.06] (2% to 6%), and if this multiplier is 0.9, then the soft range will be [0.022, 0.058].

The reason we're using a class and calling it 'instructions' instead of just subclassing from ImpreciseValue is that the concept is more general than a simple multiplier, even though that's all this represents right now. This is really a general function, which could operate as a*x + b or anything else.

    • setClosedUnitFractionSoftRangeToSameAsHard

      public static ClosedUnitFractionHardToSoftRangeTighteningInstructions setClosedUnitFractionSoftRangeToSameAsHard()
      This is for the cases where you want the soft range to be the same as hard - not tighter, like you might want in a more general case. It's particularly useful for situations where you don't have to utilize the distinction between hard and soft ranges, but are using code that is more general and takes a ClosedUnitFractionHardAndSoftRange as an input.
